fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Strictness of the least subterminal object in a coherent category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a coherent category and 0 \rightarrowtail 1 be the initial object in \mathsf { Sub } (1). Then any morphism f \colon A \to 0 in \mathcal { C } is an isomorphism.
By definition, the pullback of the least subterminal object along the unique morphism \mathsf {!} _{ A } \colon A \to 1 is the initial object in \mathsf { Sub } (A).
A regular category \mathcal { C } is said to be coherent if each \mathsf { Sub } (B) has finite unions and each f ^{*} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (A) \to \mathsf { Sub } (B) preserves them.

fr:ul.fr:li: Write down the definition of reflexive, symmetric, and transitive relations more explicitly.
